column1: Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, such as decision trees and Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. In this advanced course, we will discuss e.g. more advanced model structures, survival analysis, model validation, finding cost and utility input for your model, and how to build a probabilistic sensitivity analysis into your model.

During this course of 5 weeks, each week will be spent on a specific topic. A lecture will introduce the main elements of that week. In some weeks there will be a session with someone from the staff where each group of students can ask specific questions regarding that week’s assignment. In one week a computer exercise will be done to help students learn how to estimate and extrapolate survival curves from published data.

Subsequently, the excel-based models that were built by the students will be used for feedback sessions, to further develop modelling principles and skills. Two of these feedback sessions will be based on peer review, that is, each group will assess the models of two other groups, and report on them during the feedback session. The third feedback session will be based on model review of the faculty.
The exam is composed of six parts; the weighted average of the individual parts and the weighted average of the group parts both need to be at least a 5.0 in order to get a final grade:

column2: • 20% for introduction to results (group)

column1: Only the final grade (100%) will be published in Osiris.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course should help you to get both more theoretical and more practical knowledge on cost-effectiveness modelling. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied, based on Markov modelling. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this. Models will be developed in groups of 3 students.
By the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • set up the framing of an economic evaluation.
• construct, populate and analyse a cost-effectiveness model using a Markov model.
• critically assess models for technical errors.
• deliver a report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.
• discuss the strengths and limitations of the modelling approach taken.

column1: The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration. The analysis of trade patterns and of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of households and firms. The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics. The course focuses on the most recent and influential theories of international trade in a general equilibrium framework. The course finishes with computer simulations of these trade models and applies them to real world situations that go beyond those students studied during their bachelor program.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics. The course focuses on the most recent and influential theories of international trade within a general equilibrium framework.
• Students should understand the microeconomics foundations of general equilibrium trade theories, as well as applying them in computer simulations of real world situations.

column1: A major part of this course will touch upon the field of Asset Pricing, especially in the lectures regarding the modeling of risk. A proper understanding of risk is fundamental to many financial management applications such as capital budgeting, risk management, portfolio selection and performance evaluation. Subjects include:

column2: • Basics of Portfolio Theory & CAPM: Normative vs. positive, assumptions, testable implications, pricing errors/kernel.
• Anomalies: Size, value, momentum & reversal anomalies, why use sorted portfolios.
• Return and return distributions: Expected return, non-normality, incorporating skewness and kurtosis, the role of expectations and information.
• Utility functions: First principles (nonsatiation, risk aversion, skewness preference), types of risk aversion, downside risk, Stochastic Dominance.

• Students are able to conduct performance evaluation on investment portfolios.

column1: With respect to your previous classes in management accounting, this course offers a closer look into management accounting and control topics.

The Institute of Management Accountants (an U.S.-based institution) defines management accounting as: a value-adding continuous improvement process of planning, designing, measuring and operating nonfinancial and financial information systems that guides management action, motivates behavior, and supports and creates the cultural values necessary to achieve an organization's strategic, tactical and operating objectives. In accordance with the definition, we will examine various topics concerning management accounting and control discussed in literature and used by managers for decision management and decision control.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• To understand (new) concepts, techniques and (external) forces influencing nowadays Management Accounting and Management Control. Interaction between practical cases and theoretical concepts is essential.

column1: For maximum likelihood methods that are employed to analyze limited dependent variables, we discuss semi-parametric methods which allow one to replace sometimes restrictive distributional assumptions on the errors. For GMM, which is already a semi-parametric estimation method, we discuss how to replace the Jacobian identification method. The resulting GMM procedures are so called weak instrument robust and we discuss several papers in this area. We also discuss linear and non-linear panel data methods which are commonly applied. Here we focus on the identification of the parameters with a special emphasis on linear dynamic panel data models.
Topics: semi-parametric estimation, (linear dynamic) panel data models, weak instruments in linear instrumental variables regression models and GMM, empirical likelihood methods.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate on

1. Semi-parametric econometric methods that remain valid under less stringent assumptions than maximum likelihood, the more common econometric method. These methods allow one to analyze a wide range of applications under more general conditions.
2. Panel data: nonlinear models. What kind of approaches exist for analyzing panel data that are not of the continuous type.

3. Weak identification: In empirical applications we see that the structural parameters of many important models are only weakly identified. This implies that the standard methods for conducting econometric inference do not apply. We discuss weak identification robust inference models and show how to apply them for the linear instrumental variables regression model.

Knowledge and understanding: Conceptual awareness of the different methods discussed under the three learning goals. For the first goal this will be somewhat less detailed than for especially the last goal.
Application of knowledge and understanding: The assignment requests the discussed theory to be coded in a computer package of the students choice and applied to real data.
Making judgements: Judgement are to be made in the decision which econometric method applies to which data setting. This is rehearsed in the exam and the computer assignment.
Communication: Lectures for which handouts of the course notes are provided. Students communicate by written exam and computer assignment.
Learning skills: Reflected by independent application of the theory and methods in the assignment

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Banks, insurers and pension funds feature daily in the financial press. The credit crisis has triggered a public debate on the risks, rewards and the costs of the banking, pension and insurance industry. Fundamental questions abound. Why do banks exist? Was it a good idea in 2008 to rescue Bear Stearns, the insurer AIG and let Lehman Brothers fail? What are the cost and benefits of bank supervision? Is there too much leverage in the system? How is the sector coping with the Corona crisis? What will be the effects of this new crisis in the longer run; will it turn into a financial crisis? We extensively discuss the role and risks of the financial industry and the connection with monetary policy.

This course addresses these kinds of questions by digging deeper. Due to asymmetric information it is difficult to match the supply of credit with the demand for credit. The financial services sector is the intermediary platform that helps to bridge the divide, albeit imperfectly. Due to the asymmetric information endemic to financial services, risk management is an integral part of the services. We discuss how financial institutions’ management, regulators and supervisors deal with the various risks they face. Risk management is analyzed on the level of an individual bank or insurer, and on the systems level. Bank runs can be devastating for the entire sector and the real economy. Regulation and supervision are thus an important aspect of the government interference with the financial sector. The interplay between monetary policy and banks is essential for the understanding the risks and behavior of the financial sector at a macro scale.
The main topics of this course are:

column2: • Why do banks and other financial intermediaries exist?
• What is their business model and how has this changed over time?
• Bank fragility: Bank runs, systemic risk & diversification, regulation and supervision
• Systemic risk and the credit crises: subprime mortgage crisis, sovereign debt crisis, Covid-19 crisis
• Monetary policy, interest rate risk and credit risk: the role of conventional and unconventional monetary policy
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students understand the asymmetric information paradigm as the main explantion for the existence of financial services and the problem that this causes.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the risk management of a financial service provider and the systemic risk of the sector.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the interplay between monetary and macroeconomc policy.

• Students are able to: analyze the financial services industry using information economics and risk analysis. The students are able to analyze novel situations not treated in class, but using the class notes.
• Students are able to: analyze the interaction between the financial sector and the monetary economy.

column1: This course thoroughly familiarizes students with the theoretical background of qualitative research and its main approaches, including discourse and semiotic analysis, in-depth interviews, focus groups and ethnographic fieldwork, and less traditional methods such as photovoice. It discusses the research process as organic and addresses advantages and disadvantages of the dynamic (and often unpredictable) nature of qualitative research. These discussions are grounded in in-class exercises and close-reading of published research, paying special attention to the flexibility of the analytical frame and the relation between theory and empirical data.

<body>This course provides an overview and understanding of the more commonly used and applied multivariate, statistical techniques and the skills to design, carry out and judge sophisticated, quantitative research projects. Specifically, the course covers statistical techniques needed for data reduction (scale and factor analysis), cross-sectional analyses (multiple linear and logistic regression analysis, path analysis) and for comparative analysis (time-series analysis, multilevel and meta-analysis). The course is 'advanced' in terms of concepts and methods, rather than statistical theory or mathematics. The focus is on real-world applications, discussing the assumptions, limitations and interpretations of a wide range of statistical techniques.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Use these statistical methods in a sound and creative way, More specifically, they are able to clean and transform data, check for assumptions, conduct analyses, and interpret the output.
• Report on their research design, operationalization, execution of the data analysis, and outcomes of the data analysis and their implications in the light of a relevant research question.

column1: The Advanced Research Methods (ARM) course is first of all a methodology course that builds on the second year Research Project and prepares for the Bachelor Project. This course will:

column2: • Explain the complete research process by applying the research cycle model.
• Discuss the variety of approaches to research (research strategies) as a tool to help solve managerial problems.
• Teach approaches to critical synthesis of academic and professional literature.
• Provide a framework for critical reflection on research results.
• Teach how to use academic research as a tool to become a force for positive change in the world.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Describe the relationship between management and research
• Define the key researcher tasks in each step of the research cycle
• Articulate how to deliver quality in each of the steps of the research cycle
• Explain how to collect, read, and critically synthesize academic and professional literature
• Identify a suitable approach for own research from the existing variety of research strategies
• Explain how to write a critical reflection on research

TRJA Van Muijden, MSc', 'LRM Polfliet', 'M Felder, MSc', 'MJC Aspria, MSc', 'N Miedema', 'OS van der Woerd, MSc', 'prof.dr. RA Bal', 'S Boxebeld, MSc', 'SA Hasnida, MSc', 'SC Kuijper']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: IMPORTANT: Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for student who do have such background.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students and optional for EuHEM students. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods. The focus is not on learning new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but on interpreting results and critically reflecting on conclusions drawn by researchers, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture.

Workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where students practice the central element of the course: assessing the design, results and conclusions of existing studies. During the workgroup sessions, concepts and methods are applied after they have been introduced in on-campus and video lectures and in literature.
Students prepare cases before each session and discuss them with fellow students and with teachers during the meetings. The work in these sessions leads up to the exam.

The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, use of causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on studies that examine the use of language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography). In addition, attention will be given to the role of theory in qualitative research studies. In the final week students will present their full assessments of several published quantitative and qualitative studies.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able

column2: • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory
• to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the direct results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational measures that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results

• to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences of this distinction for design and interpretation in specific situationsto recognize and evaluate different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis)
• to evaluate the role of theory in qualitative research studies using distinctions between gap spotting and problematization as well as between inductive and deductive reasoning
• to assess the quality of qualitative research studies on the basis of quality criteria specific for qualitative research
• to recognize and evaluate different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis)
• to perform a discourse analysis of a policy report and to compare one’s own analysis with the analysis presented in a scientific publication
• to recognize and evaluate different forms of ethnography (including digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies)
• to assess the quality of observations in ethnography by using nine observation dimensions
• to evaluate ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: IMPORTANT: Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for student who do have such background.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students and optional for EuHEM students. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods. The focus is not on learning new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but on interpreting results and critically reflecting on conclusions drawn by researchers, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture.

Workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where students practice the central element of the course: assessing the design, results and conclusions of existing studies. During the workgroup sessions, concepts and methods are applied after they have been introduced in on-campus and video lectures and in literature.
Students prepare cases before each session and discuss them with fellow students and with teachers during the meetings. The work in these sessions leads up to the exam.

The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, use of causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on studies that examine the use of language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography). In addition, attention will be given to the role of theory in qualitative research studies. In the final week students will present their full assessments of several published quantitative and qualitative studies.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able

column2: • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory
• to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the direct results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational measures that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results

• to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences of this distinction for design and interpretation in specific situationsto recognize and evaluate different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis)
• to evaluate the role of theory in qualitative research studies using distinctions between gap spotting and problematization as well as between inductive and deductive reasoning
• to assess the quality of qualitative research studies on the basis of quality criteria specific for qualitative research
• to recognize and evaluate different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis)
• to perform a discourse analysis of a policy report and to compare one’s own analysis with the analysis presented in a scientific publication
• to recognize and evaluate different forms of ethnography (including digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies)
• to assess the quality of observations in ethnography by using nine observation dimensions
• to evaluate ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This module (worth 10 ECTS) trains you in methods for both quantitative and qualitative data gathering, specifically in the context of doing research in an international or comparative setting. The module focuses on 4 methods in particular: quantitative survey, ethnography, in-depth interviewing and photovoice. You will learn how to conduct these methods and their deeper methodological foundations as well as how to prepare data (where relevant) for further analysis. Together with the module Analysing Criminal Policies, which focuses on the analysis of quantitative and qualitative data, this module prepares you for conducting empirical research in the second year of the IMARC research master. Additionally, you learn how to reflect on your own position in your research and how this impacts on your findings. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successfully completing this course, the student will be able to:

column2: • Describe, compare and assess various methods for quantitative and qualitative data gathering in relation to different research questions;
• Reflect on methodological and ethical issues and on data quality in criminological research and in relation to formulating research questions;
• Select the appropriate data gathering methods for research projects;
• Understand the methodological foundations of data collection with a quantitative survey, ethnography, in-depth interviewing and photovoice;
• Independently gather and prepare quantitative data by designing original survey questions;
• Independently gather and prepare qualitative data by conducting ethnographic methods, in-depth interviews, and photovoice;
• Independently conduct small research projects using different data gathering methods.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115935,2023,Advanced Social Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. W Schinkel'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course traces the genealogy of individuation as a modality of entanglement. Modern social life and social theory are underpinned by a crucial but contingent ‘possessive individualism’. This course traces its origins as a way to doing social theory, i.e., as a way of asking how we might be together without the violence of extraction and domination. We will do so by way of readings of the histories of the commons, and by exploring Agamben’s concept of a form-of-life in the context of the late scholastic Poverty Dispute. We will try to see how modern capitalism and liberal political theory have their origins, in part, in a socialist conception of poverty and the common life. Liberalism still centers on an individuated conception of what the scholastic philosophers and theologians called dominium. In order to understand the ways modern capitalism and liberal political theory are born out of primitive accumulation, it is vital to understand both their emergence in and out of colonial domination and their gestation in the ongoing plunder of the commons by way of dominium, i.e., by private property. The course explores five alternative, non-individuated, conceptions of entanglement: form-of-life, the commons, the undercommons, incompleteness, and composition.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will be able to think and write about the history of individuation in relation to: a) the histories of the commons; b) the development of modern liberalism in tandem with the capitalist enclosure of the commons; c) the colonial divide  that marks modern liberal thought.
This course will comprise 7,5 EC for students from ESPhil.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114645,2023,Advanced Sociology of Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LE Braden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Major theoretical concepts are examined and illustrated with a wide variety of classic as well as contemporary work. The course addresses questions such as: How does artistic practice
contribute to collective understandings and social solidarity? Is culture disposed toward cooperation or conflict? What fundamental transformations have come about in modern culture?

The content for this course includes fundamental readings from sociological theory which have shaped thought on art and culture. These theoretical areas include rational choice (Smith) conflict (Marx and Weber), functionalist (Durkheim), symbolic interactionist (Mead), and formal sociology (Simmel) are all explored as we engage in deep reading and discussion. Influential work that builds on this fundamental theory within the context of art and culture is also covered.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides an advanced theoretical overview of the sociological approach to art and

Culture. Through close reading and class discussion, the course aims to help students ground critical thinking in an understanding of seminal theoretical perspectives as well as understand both continuity and change in Western thinking about culture and society. By doing this students will be able to situate research within sociological thought and improve analytical and writing skills in dealing with challenging, abstract material.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112038,2023,Advanced Statistics & Programming,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Gutt', 'dr. J van Dalen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The advanced statistics course is about acquiring a robust understanding of advanced statistical methods and techniques for business analytics, in terms of both foundation and application. In addition, the course provides training in advanced programming skills, specifically using the statistical software R.
In particular, the following topics will be covered:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The learning objectives of this course are:

column2: • Understand and apply the main statistical concepts required for advanced statistical data analysis, e.g., central limit theorem, least squares, maximum likelihood, bootstrapping, hypothesis testing, multivariate analysis, functional transformations, and limited dependent variables.

• Understand and apply the main building blocks of a programming language, e.g., data structures, flow control, environments. Solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio
• Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders.
• Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112409,2023,Advanced Time Series Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. W Wang', 'E Vladimirov']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course covers advanced topics in time series econometrics and forecasting, including:
The focus is on techniques that are found useful in applications to macroeconomic variables (such as output and inflation), and financial time series variables (asset returns and volatility).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Study state-of-the-art techniques in time series econometrics and forecasting.

• Learn how these can be useful in various macroeconomic and financial applications; with a focus on business cycle analysis and modeling and forecasting asset returns and their volatilities and correlations.
• Learn how to deal with issues, both theoretical and empirical, that an econometrician working in these areas faces.
• Gain experience with actually implementing the studies techniques, learning how to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113351,2023,Advanced Time Series Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. DJC van Dijk'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr P. Gorgi (VU), Dr Y. He (UvA), and Prof. Dr. D.J. van Dijk (EUR)

The first part of this course covers time-varying parameter models for the conditional expectation. In particular, we study the theory and practice of robust nonlinear observation-driven filtering methods for the conditional expectation.

The second part covers the formulation, estimation and testing of multivariate and high-dimensional volatility models. We also discuss the use of high-frequency data in realized volatility measurement, and its use in volatility forecasting.
The third part of the course covers non-linear regime-switching models, large-scale factor models, and forecast combination and evaluation.
For each topic, we discuss theoretical aspects of the models and methods. Real-data applications from economics and finance will show how the methods can be used in practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. understand the modern models and methods in time-series econometrics
2. critically assess articles and working papers that develop and use such time series methods
3. apply time-series econometric methods in own research
4. extend the currently available techniques where needed

Knowledge and understanding: Students should be familiar with various models and methods, understand their motivation, and be able to understand the derivation of (asymptotic) statistical properties of time-series processes and econometric methods.

Application of knowledge and understanding: The methods of analysis of asymptotic properties of techniques can be applied to specific model examples. The econometric methods can be applied empirically, using computer programs or packages that may need to be extended.
Making judgements: In empirical analysis, students need to interpret the outcome of estimation and testing results, and judge whether they provide support for the chosen model specification.

Communication: Students need to be able to report (in writing) on the outcome of empirical applications of time-series econometric methods; and they need to be able to reproduce and extend (in writing) derivations involved in the asymptotic analysis of econometric methods.

Learning skills: Students train their writing skills in assignments and written exams; and they develop analytical skill that are needed to prove theoretical properties of methods in their own research.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113352,2023,Advanced Topics in Macro I,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr. M.Z. Pedroni (UvA) and Dr. E. Pröhl (UvA)

The course introduces the core computational tools necessary to solve models on the frontier of macroeconomics. Although the models featured in the course are macro-models, the computational methods can be readily applied to structural models in, inter alia, labor economics and finance.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate

column2: • Numerical methods to solve the workhorse quantitative macro-models:
• new approaches to solving the Krusell-Smith model.

column1: Knowledge and understanding: we want the students to be able to solve numerically essentially any economic model they face in their own research; our aim for them to know and understand the basic tools necessary to do this, but also to be able to learn new methods as they become necessary.
Application of knowledge and understanding: this is a very practical course, the students should be able to apply the knowledge directly and ultimately solve the workhorse macro-models listed above.
Making judgments: programming effectively requires balancing a tradeoff between precision and time, students will begin to learn how to make these calls.

Communication: programming in a group requires very precise communication, one of the goals of this course is to lead the students in this direction; the students should also be able to communicate about frontier-level research on computational methods.

Learning skills: as mentioned above, we want to provide the students with the basic knowledge necessary to solve most macro models but also to be able to read the recent literature on programing methods to learn new skills as they become necessary.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113353,2023,Advanced Topics in Macro II,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The content of the course is adjusted annually to pick up new topics from the macroeconomic research frontier. Each class meeting (after the first) has two parts. In the first hour, students discuss a frontier paper with the aim of identifying the main contribution of the paper, determining if this paper is convincing, and coming up with an idea for further research on the topic. In the remainder of the class, one of the instructors gives a lecture introducing the topic of the frontier paper of the following week.

To ensure high quality discussions for the frontier papers, it is important that you have thought about the paper before the class meeting. To make the preparation more fun and to give you opportunities to learn from each other, we will do this using a team-based learning approach. In the first week of the course we will form teams of 2 students that will remain fixed for the duration of the course. Each team prepares a brief presentation about the paper, and submits it before the class meeting. At the beginning of each class meeting, one randomly selected team will use its presentation to lead the discussion using its presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. be exposed to hot topics picked from the research frontier in macroeconomics
2. practice their ability to identify promising research questions
3. understand content that combines recent papers from the research frontier with advanced material that bridges the gap between the first-year macro sequence and the research frontier
Knowledge and understanding: Students deepen their understanding of the topics covered in the course by reading and discussing recent papers.
Application of knowledge and understanding: Students should be able to identify promising research questions. Where necessary, novel tools that are required to understand papers will be introduced.
Making judgements: Students judge the contribution of the papers that are covered during the discussion lecture, and of the paper they select for the referee report.
Communication: Students practice their (oral and verbal) communication skills by (i) presenting papers from the research frontier and (ii) by writing a referee report.
Learning skills: Students train their presentation skills, writing skills and the skills to identify promising research questions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113004,2023,Advanced course on Applications in Flow Cytometry,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. ir. V.H.J. van der Velden', 'dr. W.W.J. Unger', 'dr. Y.M. Müller']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Flow cytometry is used by many different applications from phenotypical characterization of cell sub-populations, analysis of phosphorylated proteins, cell proliferation, cell death to detection of very rare cell sub-populations. However, each of these methods has its challenges.
This course gives users with a solid knowledge in flow cytometry the opportunity to attend lectures covering many of these applications.
These lectures are given by experienced users and therefore not only give an introduction into these applications but also suggest protocols, discuss challenges and solutions.
Participants have the opportunity to discuss questions and, most importantly, have a contact person if they want to use an application for their own research.
Using Flow cytometry by many different applications.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.
*The program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116964,2023,Advanced topics in Global Supply Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Pourakbar', 'prof.dr. AW Veenstra']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course addresses topics that are very relevant in today’s global supply chains. The aim of the elective is to provide the student with en­hanced knowledge on the complexity of truly global supply chains and how this complexity is aggravated by international legal and compliance requirements. Additionally, it aims to provide the student with en­hanced knowledge on how customs, tax law and FTAs regulate and facilitate cross-border trade and logistics in order to offer a broader and more comprehensive perspective on the mana­gement of such cross-border supply-chains. This elective contributes to the academic knowledge and skills of Master students by discus­sing the law and practice of cross-border trade and logistics from academic, business and regulatory perspec­tives. The delivery of the core course is a mix of lecturing, class discussion based on cases and exercises, and student assignments.

The learning approach as described above is very challenging because it requires the students to review and update their prior knowledge and study some new material as well. Therefore, it will be very important to prepare thoroughly for each class, by reading the required material and work on the assignments and cases.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain supply chain design issues that play a role in an international/global context
• Discuss the importance of compliance in global supply chain management and how several strategic level decisions are impacted by this
• Distinguish between different tax laws and how they impact supply chain management
• Demonstrate importance of data sharing in global supply chains, its required IT structures and legal challenges associated with this
• Identify how globalization led to the emergence of risks such as counterfeiting and learn about strategies to combat it

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116663,2023,Advanced valuation & value creation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['drs. HT Haanappel'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Understanding and analyzing business value is a key competitive advantage in decision making in M&A, private equity as well as fundamental for any other corporate investment decision. A sound business valuation requires, amongst others:

column2: • Analysis of the company, the competitive position and its strategy;
• Conduct historical financial and value creation analysis;
• A valuation method/approach that fits the valuation context and standard of value.

column1: In this course we discuss various (advanced) approaches to measure and analyze business value and value creation both from an academic and practitioners perspective. We will expand on the students basic theoretical knowledge on business valuation and value creation analysis and take this one step deeper. This course is highly relevant for students that pursue a career in M&A, private equity and/or valuation advisory.

Course attendance is not mandatory but highly recommended as topics discussed in class may be part of the individual exam. In addition, (online) sessions with guest speakers from practice may be scheduled that provide additional insights from a practitioners point of view on the topics addressed in this course.  </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn about different valuation methods and how they fit in a specific valuation context
• Understand residual income models and how they relate to DCF
• Learn how valuation from a corporate perspective differs from private equity
• Conduct LBO analysis including the importance of financial leverage
• How to cope with complex valuation issues such as: deferred taxes, provisions, leases, startups, financial distress, country risk etcetera
• Analyze a company’s strategy and business model from a value (creating) perspective
• Measure value creation using different metrics (Economic Profit, RONIC, ROIC, CFROI and ROE)
• Understand the key value drivers and how the can be used to forecast financial statements
• Consolidate the basic DCF approach and to take this knowledge one level deeper
• Understand the theoretical foundations of the WACC
• Learn best practices in estimating the parameters for WACC estimation
• Conduct valuation of companies with a changing capital structure using the APV-framework
• Perform a market based valuation using trading and transaction multiples and understand the drivers behind multiples

column1: Marketing managers require useful frameworks to effectively communicate and advertise their products and services. This course discusses all aspects involved in designing effective marketing communications campaigns. The purpose of the course is to get introduced to the major topics in marketing communications and to further develop your communication skills through written projects, team-based work, and presentations.

The goal of this course is to help you to set marketing communications objectives for a variety of products/services; to help you understand and apply the principles that are necessary for persuasive advertising, from strategic principles (information, influence, emotion and mere exposure) to more specific tactics (resistance, acceptance, message, attention); to help you generate, select and evaluate creative ideas for an advertising campaign; to help you to select appropriate media (still/motion) for a marketing communications campaign, taking into account strategic and tactical rules for implementation of the media plan; and to help you propose/design an advertising campaign and discuss, present and defend the proposed campaign.
Regular lectures: Course attendance is not compulsory for the regular lectures.

Student presentations: Course attendance is compulsory (even when you are not presenting yourself!), because you will be evaluating your fellow peers and we will be discussing the presentations during the lecture. Participation is therefore mandatory. Students who do not show up without sound justification, valid proof of it, and prior warning may be penalized for the respective assignment by their team members and/or teacher.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • recognize, understand and explain the principles behind effective marketing communication
• analyze and evaluate existing marketing communications by identifying their strengths and weaknesses
• create and develop an effective marketing campaign

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Looking at Gillette’s (2019) controversial ad on toxic masculinity, Ariel India’s (2015-now) ‘share the load’ campaign, and beauty and fashion brands’ adoption of body positivity discourses, we can see that representations and constructions of gender and body (issues) in marketing have changed over the past decades. This course will consider the concept of gender as it is represented and/or constructed in marketing materials, particularly within the beauty market. Essential to this exploration, we will adopt a cross-cultural and intersectional approach as we examine the concepts of masculinities and femininities more widely, with a special focus on the body. As the body is pivotal in contemporary consumerist societies, an overview of the current conception of the body as malleable will be provided. In order to gain an understanding of advertising trends and themes, we will explore both the producers and content of current marketing materials. As part of this course, students will have the opportunity to pitch and conduct their own research project related to the overarching focus of the course. This project will be qualitative in nature and will draw on insights from discourse analysis, thematic analysis and/or qualitative content analysis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:

column2: • Changes in the (cross-cultural) marketing landscape, particularly related to gender and the body

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Apply theoretical concepts related to gender and the body to real-life case studies.
• Execute a small-scale, qualitative empirical study of advertising discourse related to gender and/or the body.
• Present findings related to case studies and their individual research projects in a clear, comprehensive manner
• Develop a professional attitude, demonstrated through active participation and respect for others

column4: Dit practicum biedt studenten een eerste kennismaking met de praktijk van het schrijven van een beleidsadvies. Studenten zullen eerst leren over de betekenis van beleid voor jongeren en andere actoren in de stedelijke context. Vervolgens gaan studenten in een Rotterdams beleidsstuk over jeugdcriminaliteit op zoek naar de problemen die de gemeente wil aanpakken, de doelen die de gemeente nastreeft en de middelen die de gemeente inzet om de doelen te bereiken. Studenten leren de (soms impliciete) veronderstellingen in het beleidsstuk te analyseren en op basis van theoretische en empirische inzichten hier kritisch op te reflecteren.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van het practicum zijn studenten in staat om:
1. In een beleidsstuk a) gesignaleerde problemen, b) (impliciete) veronderstellingen, c) doelen en d) specifieke aanpak/maatregel te benoemen (eindterm 9):
2. Kritisch te reflecteren op voorgaande vier onderdelen aan de hand van de wetenschappelijke literatuur (eindtermen 8 en 12):

column2: • wetenschappelijke literatuur bij een specifieke vraagstelling te vinden;
• literatuur op relevantie en wetenschappelijke kwaliteit te selecteren;

• verbanden tussen bronnen te leggen, informatie uit verschillende bronnen te integreren, tegenstrijdigheden, ontbrekende informatie en inconsistenties te identificeren en bronnen kritisch te beschouwen.

column1: 3. Een inhoudelijke evaluatie van een beleidsstuk op het terrein van jeugdcriminaliteit en –deviantie te schrijven (eindtermen 13, 14, 15 en 19):

column2: • op een heldere en sluitende wijze schriftelijk te argumenteren in antwoord op een afgebakende vraagstelling;
• een samenhangende en heldere tekst te schrijven;
• een objectieve en formele wetenschappelijke schrijfstijl toe te passen;
• zowel in tekst als in de literatuurlijst op basis van de normen van de American Psychological Association (APA) voor het gebruik van en verwijzen naar bronnen te refereren;
• feedback over je werk te vragen, te ontvangen en op adequate wijze te verwerken.

column1: The list of skills necessary for working in any organisational environment is long. In this course, we will use the method of process consultation to pay attention to how people can advise. This will result in increased communication, advisory and coaching skills.

This course focuses on how students communicate and react to other people in different contexts. The course is designed to enable the students to build and develop their advisory skills and to increase knowledge of the concepts behind them, so as to widen the choice of possible actions in a given situation and to develop the understanding of the strengths and weakness of their advisory skills. By the end of the course we will have provided the students with an opportunity to learn about and practice by understanding and diagnosing contexts and give advice.

This elective is built up around lectures and workshops provided by the teacher and around 6-8 workshops (provided by the students). The sessions consist of experiential learning, theory, group exercises, and individual exercises and are provided by the lecturer, a consultant, or the teams themselves. During these sessions, we will explore various consultancy skills like questioning, analysing situations, problem sensing versus problem solution, relation building, handling intake process, teambuilding, et cetera.
The advisory skills course is all about skills; it is not something you can learn from a book. Therefore, the general rule is that you are present at all sessions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Enable students to discuss and articulate their own views on consultancy
Support students to reflect on and develop their own skills
Enable students to practice with experiential learning
Enable students to distinguish and practice with different roles of consulting

column1: After the course students are able to:

column2: Know more about and have experiences with experiential learning
Know what the essential advisory skills are and have practiced these
Have increased knowledge of concepts and know the differences between different advisory concepts
Develop a training session on one particular advisory skill.

column1: Develop a better understanding of the strength and weaknesses of own possibilities as change agent

column1: Particularly since the start of the 18th century, philosophers began to reflect on the question of art resulting in the emergence of ‘aesthetics’ as an  independent  philosophical discipline. This has resulted in the formation of various theories of and perspectives on the ‘nature’ of art – from the theory of mimesis to expression theories; from formalism to post-structuralism, and beyond. The emergence of these perspectives are linked with the role of art in society and culture, and influence the criteria under  which art is created, produced and consumed. In contemporary modernity questions on the status and legitimation of the arts are still pressing given the rise of theories about the post-postmodern, including metamodernism. In this course, various philosophers and their aesthetic theories will be discussed – e.g. Plato, Aristotle, Baudrillard, DantoHegel, Kant, Lyotard, and Nietzsche – as well as that their theories will be illustrated with reference to examples from art history. Amongst other examples, Nietzsche’s theory of the ‘tragic in art’ will be explained in the context of pre-war American blues music, and Hegel’s and Danto’s theory on the ‘end of art’ will be illustrated with examples ranging from contemporary (conceptual) art and pop culture, such as Duchamp’s urinal and Simon Reynolds’ retromania.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students will be acquainted with theories and concepts from the field of aesthetics. Following a thematic and historical overview of aesthetic theory they will familiarize themselves with various philosophical perspectives on the question ‘What is art?’. Though the course focuses on Western aesthetic theory, students are encouraged to take a comparative perspective on the study of art, art history, aesthetics and the art world.</body>

column1: Fulltime students: every no show at tutorials after the first no show leads to a subtraction of a 1 point (out of ten) from your final mark.
-Obligatory weekly critical reading response as preparation for the lectures and tutorials
Plenary lecture: 1 x per week (2 hrs)
Tutorials: 1 x per week (debate on the basis of the critical reading responses, close-reading exercises, preparatory questions, 2 hrs).
For details, see course manual on Canvas.

This module offers an introduction to a diversity of philosophical perspectives on art. Besides the classical points of view of Plato, Aristoteles, Kant, and Hegel, we will focus on 20th century philosophers: Benjamin and the Frankfurt School, Jameson, Baudrillard, Lyotard, Derrida, and Rancière. Contrary to philosophy’s traditional derogatory treatment of art, these philosophers have elaborated a new complicity between art and philosophy. Instead of speaking about art, they have started a dialogue between art and philosophy that in some cases even culminates in an aestheticization of thought and a self-reflective turn towards the artificiality of philosophy. The course is organized around three thematic clusters: 1) art and truth; 2) Marxist cultural critique; 3) modernist philosophies of art.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To acquire a global overview of the philosophical sub-discipline of Aesthetics, of its history and development, and of its contemporary relevance;
To acquire a limited but relevant toolbox for a critical attitude towards art and its changing socio-political significance;
To learn about various ways in which art and philosophy have come to interfere in the course of the 20<sup>th</sup> century.</body>

column1: For this course students are expected to already have a basic understanding of the bipolar and related disorders and depressive disorders, as well as classification of these disorders according to the DSM-5. The objectives of this course are the theoretical backgrounds, clinical presentation, treatment and differential diagnostics of these disorders in adults. A secondary objective is to study these aspects in children and young people. By the end of the course, which will be tested by means of an exam and course assignments, the student will be up to date on the most recent developments in affective disorders, as well as being able to independently study the relevant literature.

Lectures will primarily address the illnesses from a clinical perspective and these will be illustrated with video footage or imagery. Both the epidemiology and etiology will be discussed as well as psychopharmacology and psychological treatment, mainly focusing on CBT as well as there being an extensive focus on theoretical background.

There will also be an emphasis on modern models and the course will pay sufficient attention to neuroanatomy, neurobiology and psychological processes, e.g. information processing, memory, emotions and social interaction.

The course will be pay attention to the application of theoretical insights and guidelines in clinical situations. Students will work in teams on course assignments, which will be evaluated with a pass/fail qualification.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The overall objective for this course is to be able to define and describe affective disorders, classify the different affective disorders using DSM-5 and use this knowledge for diagnosis and treatment plans.
The specific aims of this course are as follows:
1. To have knowledge of the symptomatology and DSM-5 classification of affective disorders.
2. To have knowledge of the etiology of these disorders.
3. To have knowledge of the biological and psychological treatment of these disorders.
4. To be able to critically read and summarise scientific articles on these disorders.
5. The relate the above to pathology in children.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116508,2023,African Dynamics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. TA Alade', 'prof.dr. RJM van Tulder']",,"Inhoud

This subject builds on knowledge accumulated in the first two subjects. The goal is to strengthen African partnerships network, and develop sustainable project planning skills. The online learning environment forms an integral part of this course, which consists out of three modules.

Module I: A Small Private Online Course (SPOC): A Critical Engagement with Advancing the SDGs (6 ECs) aims to develop critical, transdisciplinary and innovative approaches to sustainable development. It is offered as a global classroom with invited guest students from African-based higher institutions.

Module II: Building Networks (4 ECs) aims to enables students to continue building their own network through participating in a series of webinars and excursion with key stakeholder and partners which inform EU-Dutch-African relations.

Module III: A three week Africa field study (5 ECs) is the integrative focal point of this minor to experience what students have learnt in a real-life situation. If travel is allowed by Leiden university, students can choose between participating in a structured visit to Kenya, Morocco, or South Africa. This module is self-funded, and students who cannot or do not want to partake in the field study abroad, can complete this module in the Netherlands.

column1: De ontwikkeling van het kind vormt de basis van het werk van pedagogen. De vraag die daarbij vaak centraal staat is: “hoe zorg ik ervoor dat een kind zich zo optimaal mogelijk kan ontwikkelen?”. Volgens het ecologische model van Bronfenbrenner vindt de ontwikkeling van het kind plaats door interacties tussen (kenmerken van) het kind en diens omgeving. In het blok ‘Afstemming binnen opvoeding en onderwijs’ kijken we naar (de ontwikkeling van) het kind in context. Naast de interacties tussen kindkenmerken en omgevingsinvloeden, komt ook het samenspel tussen de verschillende omgevingen van het kind aan bod. We richten we ons vooral op de onmiddellijke omgeving waarin het kind zich begeeft (microsysteem), zoals het gezin, leeftijdsgenoten en de school. Theorie wordt afgewisseld met thema’s uit de praktijk (zoals passend onderwijs, gesloten residentiële jeugdzorg en pesten) om het belang aan te tonen van de ‘fit’ tussen kindkenmerken, opvoedingssituaties en onderwijs.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • het ecologische model van Bronfenbrenner te beschrijven en toe te passen op de verschillende onderwerpen uit het blok (eindterm 1);

• de invloed van kindkenmerken en proximale processen in belangrijke microsystemen (gezin, school en peers) en de relatie tussen microsystemen (mesoniveau) op de ontwikkeling van kinderen en jongeren te beschrijven (eindtermen 1 en 5);
• de ontwikkeling van kinderen en jongeren te beschrijven binnen maatschappelijke en culturele aspecten en veranderingen over tijd in de maatschappij (het macrosysteem) (eindterm 4);

• een wetenschappelijk onderbouwde mening te vormen over de afstemming tussen belangrijke microsystemen (zoals ouders en school) in het bijdragen aan een zo optimaal mogelijke ontwikkeling van het kind (eindtermen 3 en 14)

Naast de afstudeeropdracht heeft de stage ook als doel dat de student ervaring op kan doen in de toekomstige beroepspraktijk en kan werken aan persoonlijke en professionele ontwikkeling.

column3: De Master Beleid en Politiek dient afgerond te worden met een Masterscriptie, die wetenschappelijk verantwoord dient te zijn. Er dient sprake te zijn van het gebruik van wetenschappelijke literatuur, van de toepassing van wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten, het empirisch materiaal dient op een transparante en navolgbare te zijn geanalyseerd, en bovenal dient sprake te zijn van wetenschappelijke reflectie op theorie en praktijk. Verder dient de Masterscriptie aan de gebruikelijke vereisten te voldoen, zoals een heldere en systematische opbouw (inleiding met probleemstelling, werkwijze, theoretisch kader, empirische analyse, resultaten, conclusie, reflectie) duidelijke vormgeving, correcte bronvermelding e.d. (zie Handleiding Masterscriptie). De docenten van de Master geven tevoren hun onderwerpen van expertise en belangstelling aan (zie tabblad afstudeerdocenten). Daaruit kunnen studenten kiezen. Het staat studenten overigens vrij om zelf met onderwerpen te komen. Studenten kunnen eventueel gezamenlijk een Masterscriptie schrijven. Daarbij gaat het dan wel om een groepje van twee personen. De individuele bijdrage moet echter wel herkenbaar en toetsbaar zijn, aangezien de eindbeoordeling individueel plaats vindt. Gedurende het afstudeertraject worden afspraken gemaakt over de te volgen werkwijze, de fasen in het project, deadlines en op te leveren deelproducten in het afstudeertraject. Student en docent stellen daartoe een 'contract' op met rechten en plichten voor beide partijen.

In het afstudeertraject zijn methodische seminars voorzien die gezamenlijk door alle studenten van de Master verplicht worden gevolgd. Aan de hand van concrete voorbeelden van bestaande onderzoeken zullen de studenten in groepsverband getraind worden in het doen van onderzoek. Daarbij zal het accent vooral komen te liggen op a) het werken met een probleemstelling, c) het werken met een conceptueel model, c) op het operationaliseren en meetbaar maken van centrale begrippen en d) het formuleren van wetenschappelijk gefundeerde en praktisch bruikbare aanbevelingen.

Omdat studenten een verplichte stage moeten lopen, is het raadzaam om in het eerste blok een stageplek te verwerven. In blokken drie en/of vier dient er een stage gelopen te worden en tegelijkertijd gewerkt te worden aan de scriptie. In het vierde blok wordt de Masterscriptie afgerond. Aan het begin van onderwijsblok 3 dient een definitieve opzet van de afstudeerscriptie gemaakt te worden. Iedere student beschrijft op één A4 de eerste globale opzet van de scriptie:

column5: aanleiding en doelstelling voor het afstudeer onderzoek;
probleemstelling, nader onderverdeeld in deelvragen;
opzet en wijze van aanpak, onderzoeksmethode;
theoretische invalshoek, literatuur;
empirische analyse, informatieverzameling;
concept hoofdstuk indeling.

column3: Studenten worden in blok 3 aan de hand van hun voorstel ingedeeld in scriptiekringen die worden begeleid door een docent van de opleiding bestuurskunde. Een kring bestaat doorgaans uit 3 tot 5 personen. Meestal gaat het om scripties die een zekere verwantschap met elkaar hebben. Deze kringen komen periodiek bij elkaar. In de kring worden de vorderingen tot dan toe besproken, waarbij studenten over en weer verplicht elkaars stukken lezen en daarop ook commentaar leveren. De bedoeling is dat op deze manier leerkringen ontstaan, waar studenten elkaars ervaringen en problemen met elkaar kunnen delen. Doorgaans gaat het om ervaringen waarmee een ieder tegelijkertijd wordt geconfronteerd. Deelname aan de scriptiekringen, het tijdig uitwisselen van elkaar stukken en actieve deelname zijn verplicht.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
• zelfstandig een relevante probleemstelling formuleren voor een praktijkgericht wetenschappelijk onderzoek;
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• verschillende empirische bevindingen koppelen aan theoretische concepten;
• zelfstandig (een) wetenschappelijk gefundeerde conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• persoonlijke reflectie geven ten aanzien van het eigen onderzoek;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

B Vermeeren', 'dr. NJL Cannaerts', 'JJS van der Meer', 'prof.dr. G Jacobs', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De Master Management van HR en Verandering wordt afgerond met een master thesis. In deze thesis laat de student zien in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen uitwerken en onderzoeken. De thesis of scriptie is dan ook van wetenschappelijk niveau en wordt zodanig verantwoord. Dit betekent dat wetenschappelijke literatuur wordt verwerkt, wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten worden toegepast, empirisch materiaal op verantwoorde wijze wordt verzameld en geanalyseerd en reflectie plaatsvindt op de bestuurskundige theorie en praktijk. Verder dient de Master thesis aan de gebruikelijke vereisten te voldoen, zoals een heldere en systematische opbouw (zie Handleiding Masterscriptie).

De onderwerpkeuze wordt getoetst aan de bestuurskundige relevantie waar het het studiegebied van management van HR en verandering betreft. Studenten kiezen een thema, gekoppeld aan een afstudeerkring en afstudeerbegeleider. Tijdens het verloop van het afstudeeronderzoek zullen groepjes studenten rond een gekozen thema in de afstudeerkring regelmatig met de afstudeerbegeleider bijeenkomen om de onderzoeksvoortgang en tussentijdse producten met elkaar te bespreken en verder te ontwikkelen. Gedurende het afstudeertraject worden tussen de student en de begeleidend docent afspraken gemaakt over de te volgen werkwijze, de fasen in het project, deadlines en op te leveren deelproducten in het afstudeertraject.

Aanvullend op het afstudeertraject worden de verplichte seminars van het Atelier MHVR en de seminars over methoden en technieken gevolgd (zie hiervoor de desbetreffende studiegidstekst). De seminars over methoden en technieken volgen daarbij in de tijd de opbouw van het afstudeeronderzoek zodat het afstudeertraject zo veel als mogelijk wordt ondersteund. Het afstudeertraject omvat tevens een stage (zie hiervoor opnieuw de desbetreffende studiegidstekst). De verwerving van een stageplaats vindt hoofdzakelijk in het tweede blok plaats. Ook hierbij is het Atelier ondersteunend. Studenten lopen stage in blok 3 en blok 4 en werken gelijktijdig aan de scriptie.</body>
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om een theoretisch kader te ontwikkelen en om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• zelfstandig (een) conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

column3: Met een masterthesis (scriptie) wordt de studie afgerond. De thesis vormt het bewijs van vakbekwaamheid bij het integreren van kennis. De student toont aan in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen onderzoeken en daarover op een heldere wijze te rapporteren.

De masterthesis dient wetenschappelijk verantwoord te zijn. Ofschoon organisatieontwerp of -advies wel onderwerp van afstuderen kan zijn, is kritiekloos toepassen van een bestaand 'model' niet voldoende. Er dient sprake te zijn van het gebruik van wetenschappelijke literatuur, van de toepassing van wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten, het empirisch materiaal dient verantwoord te zijn geanalyseerd, en bovenal dient sprake te zijn van wetenschappelijke reflectie op theorie en praktijk.

In de eerste helft van het jaar worden probleemstelling, opzet en werkwijze gereed gemaakt. Vervolgens wordt gewerkt aan de definitieve opzet van de thesis en vindt bestudering van relevante theoretische literatuur plaats. In het derde blok vindt, gekoppeld aan de stage, de verzameling van empirisch materiaal plaats. In het vierde blok volgt de analyse en wordt de masterthesis afgerond.

Het afstudeertraject wordt in seminars ondersteund. Deze seminars zijn opgenomen in het atelierprogramma. Het afstudeertraject heeft een omvang van 15 ECTS, ongeveer drie maanden werktijd en sluit zo goed mogelijk aan op de stage (10 ECTS), die kan worden gebruikt voor de verzameling van empirisch materiaal. Studenten die stage en scriptie combineren - wat meestal zo is - zijn gemiddeld 4-6 maanden bezig met het afstudeertraject. In het atelier zal aan het begin van blok 2 aandacht worden besteed aan het zoeken van een stageplaats en aan de eisen die er aan een stageplaats moeten worden gesteld.

Studenten schrijven in principe individueel een masterthesis. Er worden afstudeerkringen gevormd van meerdere studenten die verwante afstudeerprojecten doen. Elke afstudeerkring wordt begeleid door een docent.</mystyle></body>

column1: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the global airline industry and a rigorous economic analysis of airline competition and pricing, the role of airports and the international regulatory environment. We follow the developments in the industry since its worldwide deregulation and liberalization and examine the perspectives of its many stakeholders, in particular, airlines, airports, passengers and governments. We use concepts from industrial organization economics and micro theory in order to describe how these players have contributed to the evolution of competition in the airline industry. By reviewing older and recent developments, such as changing airline business models and the growth of emerging airlines and airports, students are challenged to think creatively about the future and the implications for the evolution of competition in the airline industry.
The following topics will be adressed in the course:

column2: • Competition models and the economics of entry and exit
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the economic theory of competition in concentrated markets and be able to apply it the context of the airline industry
• Evaluate empirical findings of the industrial organization literature from the airline industry
• Gain insight in the economics of the airline industry from a practical perspective
• Gain in depth knowledge of developments in passenger and cargo transport from a historical perspective
• Perform empirical analyses to answer questions on the effect of competition on market outcomes
