column1: In dit vak leer je de sector gezondheidszorg en het gezondheidszorgbeleid vanuit een economisch perspectief te analyseren. Met behulp van wetenschappelijke inzichten uit de algemene economie leer je waarom overheidsingrijpen nodig is voor een toegankelijke gezondheidszorg van goede kwaliteit die tegelijkertijd ook op nationaal niveau betaalbaar is. Ook leer je welke beleidsinstrumenten de overheid heeft om deze publieke doelen zo goed mogelijk te realiseren.
<body>Na afronding van het vak kun je:

column2: • de collectieve financiering van de gezondheidszorg alsmede de oorzaken en gevolgen van de stijgende uitgaven aan gezondheidszorg vanuit economisch perspectief uitleggen;
• de oorzaken en gevolgen van marktfalen op zorgverleningsmarkten, de zorgverzekeringsmarkt en op zorginkoopmarkten met behulp van inzichten vanuit de algemene economische wetenschap analyseren; en
• vanuit economisch perspectief uitleggen welk overheidsingrijpen noodzakelijk is voor het goed functioneren van markten in de gezondheidszorg.Na afronding van het vak kun je:

column1: For the management of social challenges resources are necessary. The economic discipline taught us that resources are scarce and systematic analysis is therefore required to help decide how to spend them. For public sector organizations several additional factors complicate this process. Public organizations, in contrast to private organizations, for example must balance multiple and often conflicting public values, such as equality, transparency, safety and sustainability, while also dealing with political preferences. Moreover, the results of public expenditure cannot be measured, benchmarked, and evaluated according to the single denominator of financial profit. As public resources have largely been collected through taxes rather than voluntary transactions by consumers, prior approval by taxpayers is necessary as well as public accountability afterwards. To promote transparency, fairness, and accountability in relation to the management of public resources, various procedures, rules, and regulations have been put in place. Examples are laws and processes that regulate budgeting, public procurement, and accountability. This course provides and overview of the main processes in the management of public resources (e.g., taxation, budgeting, procurement, performance review, cost-benefit analyses, accountability, and auditing) and explains how these processes play a crucial role in the management of social challenges. It also places those practices considering emerging development, for example by looking at the role of open data or how procurement can be used to drive sustainable developments and innovation. By combining plenary lectures with study visits to public sector organizations students will be able to gain insight into the necessity and complexity of the management of public resources.  </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of this course, students will be able to...

column2: Describe and distinguish between different processes related to the management of (financial) public resources, such as the budget process and procurement process, their main elements, distinctive features, and the particular risks that surround them.
Understand and explain how these processes work in agencies and how agentification/outsourcing affects these processes.
Understand and explain the role of analysis, such as cost-benefit analyses and performance reviews and their impact in deciding about the availability of resources to manage of social challenges.
Describe and explain how these processes are affected by developments such as digitalisation, inclusiveness, and sustainability.
Carry out an assignment for a public sector organization, focusing on the management of public resources.

column1: For creating a well-diversified portfolio that could sustain financial turmoil, it is important to have knowledge not only about investments in traditional markets (stocks and bonds) but also in markets of other asset classes (i.e. the pros and cons of alternative investment categories such as hedge funds, commodities, private equity and real estate) to have a successful career in finance.

The aim of this course is to deepen students’ knowledge of investments possibilities outside the traditional markets for stocks and bonds. The course is set up to be academically rigorous while practical insights from investment professionals ensure the critical link with the investment world.

The course begins with an overview of the knowledge related to investments in financial markets, e.g. the return and risk characteristics of investment strategies, the Efficient Market Hypothesis, and asset pricing models (e.g. the CAPM model). Second, we will discuss several alternative investments e.g. hedge funds, real estate, commodities, and private equity.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand and explain the theories underlying traditional investments (in stocks and bonds) and a range of alternative investments (e.g. hedge funds, real estate, commodities, and private equity).
• Understand and determine the return and risk characteristics and the trade-off of traditional investments and a range of alternative investments.
• Create portfolios consisting of traditional and/or alternative investments and to determine their performance.
• Determine whether and which (traditional and/or alternative) investments add value to an existing portfolio.
• Use Excel to construct, calculate and evaluate the performance of portfolios consisting of traditional and/or alternative investments.
• Understand and summarize academic articles published in top finance journals.

column1: <body>Cultural analysis is an approach to the study of culture through its objects. In this course you will be introduced to some of the fundamental methods and concepts of cultural object analysis. You will learn how to find and select meaningful objects for cultural analysis, and explore different approaches to studying the meaning and significance of cultural objects their role within and relationship to the cultural context(s) in which they circulate, as well as how people make or have made sense of these objects. Positioned somewhere between textual analysis and cultural studies, cultural analysis is fundamentally and by necessity interdisciplinary, and uses as its tools concepts that have often travelled across disciplinary boundaries. During this course you will engage with theories and concepts that you may recognize from literary analysis, visual analysis, art history, discourse analysis, gender and postcolonial studies, and media studies. In this course you will learn how to operationalize these theories and concepts into a methodology for the analysis of cultural objects as a critical, reflexive, and situated research praxis.</body>

column1: <body>Cultural analysis is an approach to the study of culture through its objects. In this course you will be introduced to some of the fundamental methods and concepts of cultural object analysis. You will learn how to find and select meaningful objects for cultural analysis, and explore different approaches to studying the meaning and significance of cultural objects their role within and relationship to the cultural context(s) in which they circulate, as well as how people make or have made sense of these objects. Positioned somewhere between textual analysis and cultural studies, cultural analysis is fundamentally and by necessity interdisciplinary, and uses as its tools concepts that have often travelled across disciplinary boundaries. During this course you will engage with theories and concepts that you may recognize from literary analysis, visual analysis, art history, discourse analysis, gender and postcolonial studies, and media studies. In this course you will learn how to operationalize these theories and concepts into a methodology for the analysis of cultural objects as a critical, reflexive, and situated research praxis.</body>

column1: Many criminologists end up in positions where they are confronted with research that is important for policymaking, as a user, a client, or researcher. This course focuses on critical analysis, problem solving and research skills in the field of research on criminal policies. The course trains students to be critical consumers of research as well as to develop research that is relevant to policy and practice. First, the students will learn about the key types of policy evaluation research, the methodological and practical issues involved and practical solutions for conducting evaluation research in practice. Second, students learn and perform qualitative and quantitative data analysis and they learn to critically reflect on those methods. Thirdly, students will develop an understanding of the ethical dilemmas involved in conducting criminological research for public policy making. Lastly, it contributes to a better understanding of the ways in which research findings can be transferred into policy making and to an understanding of the limits thereof.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Upon completion of the module, the student will be able to:

column2: • Assess the design of a program evaluation, process evaluation, and effect evaluation on the strengths and weaknesses of the research design, the possible methodological and practical challenges (in terms of feasibility, validity and reliability) and identify possible solutions;
• Independently create a research design for a process or effect evaluation and reflect on the methodological challenges;

• Critically reflect on the interests and roles of policymakers and researchers in commissioned studies and identify the ethical dilemmas the researcher can encounter in the design and execution of research in a policy-oriented context;
• Independently (select and) apply various qualitative data analysis (QDA) methods using ATLAS.ti transparently;
• Critically reflect on the assumptions and statements of various European Union actors concerning the policy framework on ‘the protection of victims of human trafficking’;
• Critically reflect on the use of scientific knowledge in political debate, policy-making and evaluation;
• Formulate hypotheses for statistical data analysis, based on known criminological theories and research relevant to evaluate a specific policy measure;
• Independently design a multivariate analytical model for analysing criminal policy (e.g. regression analysis), assess its quality, and report and critically reflect on the findings.

column1: In this minor we apply psychology, behavioral and health economics to understand and develop interventions to improve health and behavior.
Take a look at our video here and learn more!

People generally attach great importance to their health and would name it as one of the key aspects for a happy life. Nonetheless, many people do not adhere to a healthy lifestyle and therefore seem to behave in conflict with their own life goals. Smoking, physical inactivity, rejecting vaccination and screening or not adhering to physicians’ recommendations are popular examples. This raises the question as to how we can change behaviour and improve health and wellbeing. This is a question of concern to individuals, schools, companies and governments, and is the central question in this minor.

The past decades have seen many different approaches as to how behaviour change can potentially be realised. Traditionally in many fields, but economics especially, individuals are seen as ‘rational decision-makers’, i.e. they know what they want, and make reasoned choices to achieve their goal of a better health and happiness. In this view, policies or interventions to promote behaviour change are only necessary when individuals are misinformed, or choice is limited.
In particular, two issues arise with this traditional approach to behaviour (change) that are the focus of this minor:

column2: • For most people health is very different from most other commodities. Questions of how to approach issues in health are the domain of health economics, which is one of the core components of this minor.

• We all know that often people do not behave rationally when it concerns their own health and wellbeing. Understanding such non-rational behaviour requires insights from for example psychology and sociology, which are both central to behavioural economics – the second core component of this minor.

column1: You will be introduced to the key concepts from behavioural and health economics, with examples related to health and healthcare. We will apply these concepts to i) understand health behaviour, both rational and non-rational, and ii) explore what this means for individuals, organisations and governments aiming to promote healthier behaviour (e.g., through nudging, boosting, incentives and regulation). Using these insights, you will select an actual health issue stakeholders from the field are trying to understand and change, in order to design an intervention, and reflect on it critically.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain and apply the traditional economic approach to rational choice, and discuss the merits and limitations of this approach for understanding and changing behaviour.
• Apply basic economic and mathematical tools to demonstrate and/or explain how traditional assumptions about rationality are violated (e.g. using behavioural models).
• Give examples of heuristics and biases in intertemporal choice, risky choice and social choice.
• Apply these behavioural insights to understand and analyse health behaviour, in at least two settings: lifestyle choice, and patient and physician decision-making.

• Differentiate between, provide arguments for and against, discuss challenges, and give examples of appropriate applications in health for the following four common (policy) interventions: a) nudging, b) boosting, c) (financial) incentives, d) regulation.
• Apply insights from behavioural and health economics to develop and evaluate an intervention aimed at promoting health and/or wellbeing.

column1: The course ‘Analytics in Accounting & Financial Management’ introduces students to analytical methods that support the creation and communication of business-relevant knowledge from accounting and financial management data. Accounting and financial management specialists inside and outside the firm use data analytics in various tasks. Examples of such tasks are forecasting sales, uncollectible accounts, and cash flows to support budgeting and planning decisions; journal entry validation to support data accuracy analysis and fraud detection; and investment selection using big data and scenario modeling. This course familiarizes students with essential analytical tools in accounting and financial management. It covers the following areas:

column2: Data management. Creating knowledge from data requires identifying and managing decision-relevant data. The course brings students hands-on experience with relational database management systems (SQL), eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) data, and R procedures for collecting, cleaning, and structuring data.
Data visualization. Students learn to create data visualizations and dashboards that help evaluate data quality, communicate insights, and support informed decision-making.

Analysis of structured financial data and textual data. Students learn to understand and apply descriptive analytics (e.g., identifying red flags in accounting data), diagnostic analytics (e.g., understanding cost variances), and predictive analytics (e.g., in financial forecasting, budgeting, and reporting) using the above tools and (un)supervised machine learning techniques (such as regression, k-nearest neighbor classification, and decision trees). Students also learn to understand and apply various approaches in textual data analysis, helping them capitalize on the increasing availability of textual data relevant to accounting and financial decisions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Use relational databases and eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL)
• Create data visualizations that support decision-making in accounting and financial management
• Evaluate supervised machine learning techniques, including (logistic) regression, k-nearest neighbor classification, and decision trees
• Apply descriptive, diagnostic, and predictive analytics in various accounting and financial management contexts
• Apply programming skills to analyze, visualize, and communicate accounting, financial, and textual data
• Create a strategy and plan to address a problem in accounting and financial management using data analytics and communicate the findings

column1: Consumers use various technologies in their everyday life, such as mobile applications, internet browsers, social networks, and wearables. In doing so, consumers leave a digital footprint - a stream of data that describes their online activities. Sometimes, they explicitly share content with other people (e.g., social networks, forums) or have direct communication with a company (e.g., online customer service). Data that consumers intentionally submit online is defined as active digital footprint. At the same time, consumers also leave a passive digital footprint: their search history, the news they read online, the location and time when they use a device. Both active and passive digital footprints can reveal consumer attitudes, interests, and preferences. This brings numerous opportunities and challenges for companies, consumers, and public policy makers.

Attendance is strongly encouraged, but is not factored directly into your grade. I assume you take responsibility for your own learning trajectory and check Canvas regularly for up-to-date information. If you must miss class for some reason, please send me an email, before the absence if that is possible. If you do not send me an email, I will simply assume you have decided not to attend.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Adopt advanced scientific computing practices in their data collection and analysis workflow
• Recognize legal and ethical aspects that impact how companies collect and use digital footprints
• Provide managerial and policy recommendations supported by empirical results and theoretical insights from studying the literature

column1: <body>This course gives an introduction to the application of econometric techniques to problems in business and management. Focus will be upon the implementation of the linear regression model with non-experimental data. Attention will be paid to estimation, hypothesis testing, specification analysis, misspecification, interpretation, causality, model choice, autocorrelation, heteroskedasticity, and robust inference. A large number of illustrations will be covered and students are expected to complete a small empirical research project. The course will conclude with a short introduction to causal infererence using instrumental variables and GMM.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the course Applied Econometrics you will be introduced to the linear model in econometrics, including OLS, GLS and IV estimation. Towards the end of the course you should be able:

column2: • to interpret and evaluate estimation results, including adequacy of employed estimators and test procedures;
• to judge the appropriateness of certain assumptions (homoscedasticity, linearity, parameter constancy), and to test them statistically;
• to perform your own empirical study, including model building and selection, misspecification testing, and economic interpretation and forecasting.

column1: Game theory is a mathematical tool, which provides a unified analytical structure for studying all situations of conflict and cooperation. It is viewed as one of the outstanding intellectual advances of the last decades (as exemplified by several Nobel Prizes). Game theory intersects with many disciplines. This course will introduce the basic ideas of game theory and apply them to the strategic settings in different fields including economics, business, political science, history, international relations, and evolutionary biology.

A setting is strategic when it is characterised by interdependence, i.e. in order to choose the best action a person needs to consider how others around him decide on their actions. A strategy, the core concept in this course, is fundamental to social interaction. Throughout the course we will incrementally introduce game theoretic concepts in order (i) to understand how individuals actually behave in strategic situations and how strategic forces influence final outcomes (positivist approach), and (ii) to be able to say something about how they should be advised to behave (normative approach).  This course includes topics from non-cooperative, cooperative, and evolutionary game theory.
The aim of this course is three-fold:

column2: • Master the game-theoretic way of thinking;
• Practice the logic of a game-theoretic argument by applying it to examples in different disciplines;
• Be able to improve upon multi-person strategic situations.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of this course is three-fold:
1. Master the game theoretic way of thinking;
2. Practice the logic of a game-theoretic argument by applying it to examples in different disciplines;
3. Be able to improve upon multi-person strategic situations.
​To be more precise, by the end of the course you will be able to:
- Represent strategic situations in a game-theoretic form by distinguishing different elements of the game;

- Solve for the equilibrium of the game by appropriately applying different solution concepts (Nash equilibrium, mixed strategy Nash equilibrium, sub-game perfect equilibrium, Bayesian Nash equilibrium, Perfect Bayesian Nash equilibrium, Shapley value, Core);
- Evaluate equilibrium results from the efficiency perspective;
- Formulate suggestions regarding how to improve inefficient outcomes.</body>

column1: Game theory is widely applied in the social sciences in general and in economics in particular. Examples include the analysis of geopolitical conflicts, committee behavior, bidding behavior in auctions for Treasury bills and CO2 emission rights, lobbying activities, and legal procedures.

Game theory is a modelling approach that consists of 6 key ingredients that together aim to describe, prescribe and predict human interaction in situations with room for cooperation and conflict. Five ingredients are used to convert “a situation” into a description of a game:

column2: • A description of which player knows what when
• A description of which players can make a move when.

column1: The sixth ingredient characterizes the solution of the game:
Game theory can be used in a rational choice approach to human behavior but also in a behavioral approach.

column2: • covers the 6 key elements of the analysis in progressively more advanced settings, covering static and dynamic games, games with perfect and imperfect information, and games with complete and incomplete information;
• shows game theory in action in a host of economic situations, with examples taken from economics and business;
• builds upon the basic game theory that is taught in first year, in Microeconomics and Mathematics and game theory. A refresher of the material covered in these courses will be offered.

column1: The course is invaluable as preparation for any advanced undergraduate and graduate course in economics, finance, marketing and accounting. It will also be useful later in life—professional and private—as it helps to think about your long-term interests and the interests of other persons, the reactions of others to your actions and the consequences these may have for you.

column1: In an era where Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are not just buzzwords but transformative forces, the landscape of strategy consulting is undergoing a seismic shift. The rise of AI technologies threatens to automate various job roles, including those that require creative and strategic thinking (Brynjolfsson & McAfee, 2014, ""The Second Machine Age""). This course is designed as a strategic response to this existential challenge. It aims to equip students with the essential knowledge and skills to act as a liaison between consulting clients and technical data analysts, a role increasingly in demand as firms seek to integrate AI into their strategic operations.

The course adopts a NON-technical approach, requiring NO prior knowledge of mathematics or programming. No coding will be required. It is tailored for students aspiring to careers in strategy consulting, project management, or strategic entrepreneurship. The curriculum provides a comprehensive understanding of how ML techniques can be applied across various business domains, from supply chain to customer experience, to enhance both efficiency and creativity in problem-solving.

Course content includes an introduction to ML, its applications in consulting, and its strategic deployment in various business sectors. The course also covers the steps involved in client project propositions and final analysis delivery, contextualized within change management frameworks. Moreover, it delves into how entrepreneurial ventures leverage ML to outcompete incumbents.

Guest lectures from industry leaders will provide insights into what top consulting and entrepreneurial firms look for when recruiting non-technical strategy consultants and project managers, thereby offering students a competitive edge in the job market.

By the end of this course, students will be well-equipped to navigate the rapidly evolving intersection of AI, creativity, and strategic consulting, thereby future-proofing their career prospects in an increasingly automated world.
Participation in class discussion and activities contributes to 10% of the grade.
No attendance will be taken during class.
Highest participation grade will go to students that actively engage in class discussions during the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Identify business problems and questions that require machine learning solutions
• Recognize the potential ML solutions and techniques for different (client) problems
• Report both on the ML approach needed for solving the problem, and also present the results and draw meaningful conclusions for a non-technical audience
• Interlink between technical and non-technical agents (i.e. data analysts vs clients), and coherently communicate ML problems and solutions between the two
• Leverage AI for higher creativity and efficiency for consulting and entrepreneurship

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. M. Giuliodori (UvA), Dr. A. Pick (EUR) and Dr L.C.G. Pozzi (EUR)

This course will provide a comprehensive set of applications of econometric techniques that are commonly used to address questions of interest to academics, business and central-bank economists in the field of macroeconomics and international economics. The key objective of the course is applying these techniques rather than deriving econometric and statistical properties of estimators.

Each session will be structured as follows. First, the specific econometric topics will be introduced and their key elements outlined. Then, a critical discussion of the key empirical papers applying those methods will be provided. Finally, we will conclude each session providing information on the datasets, econometric package/commands, and research questions that students will be asked to address in the take-home assignments.
• Weeks 5, 6, and 7: Macro Panel Data Methods

column1: <body>This course focuses on both qualitative and quantitative research methods. Students will need to apply research methods in the research workshops and, of course, in their MA thesis project. In addition, they need to be able to assess the quality of studies carried out by others. This course will familiarize them with a number of essential concepts and approaches in empirical research. We start out exploring the logical links between research questions, sampling, and choosing the best method to answer your question. General notions such as inductive and deductive research shall be introduced and linked to choices to be made during the research process. After this introduction, several research methods will be introduced. Regarding qualitative research, the emphasis will be on different types of interviews (semi-structured in-depth interview, narrative interview, active interviewing) and how to analyze these systematically. Quantitative research will also be addressed by familiarizing students with the statistical program SPSS, with a focus on assessing relations between (sets of) variables and reflecting on causality.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Having completed this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand which sampling methods best fit which research questions
• Understand research ethics and their impact on doing empirical research
• Distinguish between different methods of qualitative research, most notably different types of interviewing and when to apply these
• Understand and carry out descriptive statistics and assess (causal and non-causal) relations between dependent and independent variables

column1: This course provides students with knowledge of econometric methods which are relevant for applied economics. In particular, it first refreshes the essentials of the standard regression model. It then covers methods that can be useful when the dependent variable of interest is endogenous: instrumental variables and linear panel data models. Finally, the last part of the course covers methods for binary outcomes.

Students follow a hands-on approach to understanding empirical econometric methods, in this way getting the opportunity to develop experience with the application of these methods in their own field of specialization.

The course consists of online materials, question hours and group practical work. The lecturers present and discuss each method and relevant applications in online videos. For each part of the course: i) a first set of videos introduce the empirical methods; ii) in a second set of videos, the lecturers explain how to implement the methods in Stata, with special focus on the interpretation of the results. Students put into practice the acquired skills through group assignments which are practical empirical applications with real world datasets.
1. Linear regression models (linear regression; conditions for causality; specification tests, model selection).
2. Endogeneity and instrumental variables estimation (causality, identifying and dealing with endogeneity)
3. Linear panel data models (random effects models; fixed effects models; difference-in-differences).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To know about econometric methods relevant in different fields of applied economics.
• To know what methods are suited for analysis of cross-sectional, panel and choice data.
• To know the advantages and disadvantages of each method.
• To know how to interpret the results obtained.
• To be able to use the statistical software Stata to analyze (large) datasets.
• To be able to apply the methods learned using Stata.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr H. Bloemen (VU), Prof. Dr. M. Lindeboom (VU), and Prof. Dr. B. van der Klaauw (VU)
Many empirical questions in economics are answered using individual level

data and require analyzing individual behavior. This course focuses on estimating models that relate to behavior of individuals. We consider dynamic panel data models, duration models, multinomial models, treatment evaluation models and structural models. To estimate these models we apply techniques like OLS, IV, Maximum Likelihood, GMM and nonparametric approaches. Important topics in the course are the use of various types of fixed effects in different models, flexible model specifications and the choice of explanatory variables. The emphasis of the course is on identification, estimation and interpretation rather than a thorough treatment of the asymptotic properties of the estimators. During the course applications of the
different methods are discussed, mainly in the fields of labor economics, health economics, and the economics of education.

The key objective of the course is applying microeconometric techniques rather than deriving econometric and statistical properties of estimators. After the course student should be able to decide about the appropriate model, apply the estimation method correctly, and they should be able to interpret the estimation results.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• be able to interpret the estimation results.

column1: The course consists of two parts: personnel economics and public economics.

column2: • The first part of the course focuses on incentives and workers' motivation inside organisations. The role of monetary and non-monetary incentives in motivating, selecting, and attracting workers to organisations is studied. Topics include the effects of pay-for-performance on motivating and selecting workers, optimal hiring and firing policies, education, team-work, promotion tournaments, and benefits.

• The second part of the course focuses on the functioning of markets in case of public goods, externalities, and asymmetric information, and the role of the government in reducing the inefficiencies that arise when markets do not function perfectly. This includes distributional questions, and a discussion of the limits of government intervention. The normative analysis of government intervention is pared to a positive analysis of collective decision-making.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand how economic theory can be used to study how organizations can attract, select, and motivate employees.
• Understand how economic theory can be used to study the functioning of markets in case of market failures, and the effects of government intervention on efficiency and distribution.

• Apply concepts and techniques taught in the first-year Microeconomics course and the Mathematics courses to analyze the effects of proposed responses to problems faced by decision-makers in the public sector as well as in organizations more generally.

column4: This course is meant as a preparation for the research you will have to do for your Master’s thesis. You will refresh old knowledge and gain new knowledge concerning the most common univariate and multivariate statistical techniques. In addition, this course will teach you ways to analyse complicated research designs with multiple variables, and evaluate the use of these techniques in actual research.

The course builds on the statistics you learned during courses 1.3, 2.2 and 2.8/3.5. The techniques that you will learn during this course are generalizations of these familiar techniques. The techniques discussed in this course are multiple regression, Moderation and Mediation, ANOVA, ANCOVA, repeated measures ANOVA, and mixed ANOVA. These techniques all stem from the general linear model (GLM).

column3: The emphasis is on being able to apply these techniques based on research questions such as:

- “Is a new treatment method more effective than treatment as usual in reducing anxiety problems among depressed older people? And is this effect still visible a year after completion of the treatment?” Or:
- “What aspects of internal control are effective predictors of counterproductive behaviour at work?”

Each technique will first be studied extensively in a lecture, after which the student will gain more insight into the techniques by working on data-analysis assignments that will be discussed during the tutorial group meetings.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The objective of this course is to consolidate and expand your knowledge and understanding of several (univariate and multivariate) data analysis techniques that are common in the field of psychological research.
The emphasis is on the application of the techniques in actual research and the interpretation of results.

column3: After taking this course you should be able to choose the appropriate data analysis technique given the research question, perform the analysis in SPSS, check the assumptions, interpret the results, and report them in accordance with the APA norms. Furthermore, you should be able to read research articles more critically.</body>

column1: Applied Statistics 1 introduces exploratory statistics, probability theory and explanatory statistics.
Topics include statistical measures and graphics for the exploration of a single variable and relations between two variables, inlcuding linear regression.
In addition, probability theory is treated (together with Bayes theorem) and distributions of random variables, such as the Poisson distribution that is important in the analysis of queuing problems.
Other topics are the estimation of the mean and hypothesis testing of the mean with known and unknown standard deviation.
In addition, hypothesis testing for variances and differences in proportions are treated. Some of the exercises make use of SPSS.

• Develop an ability to meaningfully interpret statistical findings in a business and economics setting.

• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert eenmaal per jaar cursussen Arabisch in de periode januari-juni.
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Arabisch gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 11 en maximaal 15. Bij minder dan 11 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je aanwezig te zijn.
• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115103,2023,Argumentation and Rhetoric in the Public Sphere,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AG Fokkema'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

When listening to a UN peace intervention speech or reading an Op-ed piece attacking the exploits of an oil company in Nigeria, you often have a hunch about how well (or how misleadingly) this act of public discourse is construed. When scrolling down that Op-ed piece to see the audiences’ reactions, you equally have a gut feeling about the validity of those reactions. This course helps you to establish a solid backing for these intuitions, enabling a sophisticated critical qualitative content analysis of argumentation in the public sphere. But it will do more.

Argumentation is used in persuasive communication, such as in the examples above. Far more interestingly though, argumentation structures are also used in any communicative act of decision making, whether these be on private matters or regarding commercial transactions, health care, or political issues. This is where “real-life” argumentation as part of human communication comes into play. This course seeks to raise an awareness exactly of these processes of decision making and will stimulate students to analyze and monitor such processes in both their own and the public sphere, paying specific attention to cultural and national idiosyncrasies and differences. To this end, students will first read and think about the building blocks of argumentation. They will be constantly encouraged to match these elementals to real life situations. Analyzing argumentation therefore is no end in itself but serves to grasp the potential of decision making.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The role and use of argumentative and rhetorical strategies in communication in the public sphere;

column2: • Conduct a critical content analysis of argumentative and rhetorical strategies in communication in the public sphere;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How people consume arts and culture, how they make meaning in and through their engagement with art and how taste formations and patterns of cultural consumption remake social inequality remain critical issues in sociology. Moreover, for the cultural industries, questions of how to develop and expand art audiences, how to explore and cultivate novel forms of cultural participation and how to address structural inequalities in the sector present timely and important concerns. In this course, we will therefore become familiarised with and critically reflect upon some of the key debates and theories that focus on the nexus between art, taste, cultural participation, social identities, and inequality. In particular, students will become acquainted with how art and cultural consumption – both offline and online – have been theorised in relationship to subjectivity formations, the self and the negotiation of wider social, political and spatial identities, as well as with regards to the reproduction of classed, raced and gendered inequalities. We will develop an interdisciplinary approach to analyse the multifaceted ways in which people consume and engage with culture, how they make meaning in and through their participation with art and how people’s tastes and consumption practices tie in with wider social and economic institutions, structures and hierarchies. To that end, this research-led course brings into conversation seminal scholarship in sociology, cultural studies and media studies with contemporary research on and examples of arts and cultural production, and drawn from different national and genre contexts.

Rather than merely focusing on one particular topic or theoretical perspective in the study of arts and cultural participation, this course will shed light on a variety of different yet partly interconnected themes, concerns and theoretical approaches. We will start by outlining some general concerns in the sociology of arts and culture today, before zooming more closely into questions of cultural participation and the importance and role of the audience. In this connection, we will explore how audiences are not passive recipients of art but actively take part in the cultural circuit of production, dissemination and consumption. Following on from this, we will discuss in more detail how arts and culture present meaningful sites of social and political identity formation, both locally and transnationally, online and offline. We will also analyse how people’s specific cultural tastes and consumption practices can become vectors of classed, gendered and raced boundary-drawing and hence contributors in the remaking of social hierarchies and inequality. Lastly, we will think about different spaces of cultural consumption and explore the ambivalent and contested role of cultural policy for questions of audience development and cultural participation with a special emphasis on ‘diversity’ in the arts discourses.

By encouraging students to carefully think through these different topics and apply different theoretical vantage points to the study of art audiences and cultural participation, the course moreover seeks to support students in developing independent research and writing skills which will help them, amongst others, with their Master theses.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students will develop a critical understanding of core debates and new developments in the sociology of arts and culture with a focus on art engagement, taste, cultural participation and consumption.
• Students will learn to apply different theoretical perspectives to the analysis of contemporary trends and dynamics in the cultural and creative industries.

• Students will learn how to examine a range of cultural and media texts including film, music, art, TV, and digital media, and become familiarised with a variety of (qualitative) methodological approaches.

• Students will learn to present and discuss their analyses in class and in small groups, developing the skills to communicate ideas effectively, both verbally and in writing, and work both autonomously and in dialogue with others.

column1: The aim of this course is to present to non-arts students an introduction to the historical development of (Western-) European art and culture from the late Middle Ages onwards. We question how developments of the past have resulted in the art world as we know it today. Students will be able to reflect on these developments and the context in which they took place, and be able to identify and discuss important works of art/art movements in visual arts, architecture, literature, and philosophy.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Knowledge of – and insight into – the major concepts and features for each of the discussed periods in the history of Western (-European) art and culture.
• Knowledge of – and insight into – the different movements (both in terms of style and culture in general) and the most important artists and art works, from the Late Middle Ages onwards.
• Enumerate important movements in the history of Western (-European) art and culture accompanied by their main characteristics and examples.

column2: • Being able to reflect critically on the historical development of Western (-European) art and culture, from the Late Middle Ages onwards.

column1: <table cellspacing=""0"" class=""MsoTableGrid"" style=""border-collapse:collapse; border:none; margin-left:-19px; width:690px"">

column4: This course provides an introduction to the sociology of culture and the arts as a scientific discipline. The goal is to familiarize students with the social character of the production, distribution and appreciation of art and cultural products by applying relevant theoretical sociological concepts and approaches to the practice of the broad art and cultural sectors. We will start with the relations between art and society as they were considered in classic sociological perspectives, but then take into account how this is complicated by intermediate layers of stakeholders. In this respect, we will focus on such questions as what is an artist, who is involved in constituting the arts, how do we know what is art (and what is not), how do the cultural industries decide what to make, why do people consume art and why do they differ so much when it comes to taste for the arts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Artificlal Intelligence is widely recognised as a technology that will disrupt and transform the way we do things in many walks of life. In view of the potential development, its impact on processes and actions will very likely transform professional behavior in the private and public sector and increasingly also the ways in which we develop scientific research. A reduction of these consequences of new technology to the field of techno science is pointless, where we already see the debate evolving into the entire academic and professional landscape. In Erasmus University Rotterdam’s teaching and research this development has led to an increase in attention to AI across the board, dispersed over the various schools and curricula. As part of a strategic impulse that allows student from every school the benefit of the accumalation of new insights this minor on the topic of AI is on offer.

The debate in the European context is very much focussed on trustworthy human centered AI, which broadens the perspective from the pure engineering of good AI to a holistic approach that embraces the ethical, legal, social, economic an cultural aspects (ELSEC) of this technological change. Moreover, Erasmus University Rotterdam is very strong in medical and social sciences and humanities disciplines which determines its student population. Consequently, to serve the wide variety of students with the contemporary developments around AI inevitably leads to the multidisciplinary approach of the topic as reflected in the (sub)title. Students need to be confronted with the ELSEC aspects, in order to make the connection with their major field of study, and with the diversity of disciplines that study the effects of AI introduction into research and professional practices. That multidisciplinary character of the teaching is not limited to the fields present in the EUR curricula, but comprises the technological side of AI; to the level that can reasonably be attainable for SSH bachelor students. For the computer science discipline, the ambition is therefore to bring student insight into what type of perceptions of reality define computation, some of the process behind this and what is the specific nature of AI in the field of computation. Where concrete and active skills in mathematics cannot be presupposed, a familiarity with model thinking is the best way to learn about how IT engineers work.

Students will be confronted with the variety of disciplinary perspectives on AI by activating lectures, exposure to the basic building blocks of AI development, and self-study materials, whereby all participants will be brought outside their regular comfort zone of disciplinary experience. This learning process will be continued and reinforced by the groupwork that is embedded in the program of the minor. The groups will by definition show a multi-disciplinary composition. The students will be coached particularly in the discovery of unfamiliar perspectives and the final assessment product will be scored on the level of discipline combination/integration. Student will be expected to reach a foundational level of insight into the benefits and risks of AI deployment in areas within their field of study, but also basic level of insight into the benefits and risks in other areas.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• ILO 2 Illustrate the basic principles of AI through the use of conceptual models
• ILO 3 Understand the modular development and learning processes prominent in current AI development

column1: Multi-disciplinary - Students compare and contrast knowledge surrounding AI in society through a multi-disciplinary lens

column2: • ILO 4 Identify and describe the opportunities and challenges when AI is developed and deployed (in society) from at least 2-3 disciplinary perspectives.

column1: Disciplinary - Students deepen their disciplinary understanding of AI’s implication, threats and opportunities

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What counts as “fair” or “good” in AI design and use? What does a “compassionate” and “inclusive” Artificial Intelligence (AI) driven system of healthcare, welfare or education system look like? How do (cultural) values matter in design and implementation of AI for consumers around the world? Whose morality counts in embedding these values? These are just some of the contemporary and urgent questions we face as nations find themselves competing in the AI arms race. The field of artificial intelligence (AI) and ethics has exponentially grown in the last decade with rising and contested discourses on the responsibilities and impacts of innovations such as automation, deep learning, and predictive analytics in our everyday lives. This course critically examines the design, implementation and impacts of AI in everyday life and invites students to reimagine alternative paradigms that align with values such as sustainability, democracy, inclusiveness, and equity for an ethical global future. Students deconstruct normative notions and universalisms related to technological innovation such as privacy, trust, transparency, explainability, and value based design. These efforts are essential if we are to design ethical media systems and regulatory bodies and policies for the wellbeing of a global public.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114954,2023,Artificial Intelligence: The Present and Future of Work,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. F Grommé', 'RA Morgan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course we will consider what happens if artificial intelligence (AI) is used in the workplace to (attempt to) 'augment' or even 'replace' people. These questions are becoming increasingly urgent as employers increasingly experiment or implement data-driven technologies and machine learning. In practice, we see a variety of developments around work. In some sectors, for instance in financial services, tasks can be increasingly automated. Yet, new types of work are also emerging with AI, such as cloudwork.

In this course you will learn how you can contribute to debates and practical dilemmas about AI and work from different social science perspectives. Starting from the idea that technologies never act alone, but depend on social institutions and relations, we will discuss the consequences for different aspects of the work context. Examples of topics are: the practical and ethical dilemmas facing professionals such as surgeons or judges, the effects of national policies, the reproduction of existing inequalities, and underlying notions of ‘intelligence’ that shape technologies. We also turn the debate around: what do developments around AI tell us about the role of work in our lives?

IMPORTANT: please do not register if you cannot commit to group work on Fridays. You will work on real-life challenges around AI and work formulated by companies and public organisations (in previous years: Port of Rotterdam, CBS, Ernst & Young, and more. But the organisations vary each year). You and your group are expected to maintain regular contact with these organisations. This can be an enriching experience but also requires commitment to the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyse AI-enabled technologies as situated, socio-technical systems
• Interpret AI-enabled automation in the context of labour relations and policies
• Assess the ethical consequences of AI for professionals
• Assess the consequences of AI-enabled automation for work organisations and professional fields
• Develop recommendations for addressing practical issues regarding the application of AI in organisations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114626,2023,Arts Education,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. CJM van Eijck'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Arts education is an important institutionalized way to familiarize people with the arts. School, governments and cultural institutions invest in this for very different reasons. Arts education early in life could make it more likely that pupils will evolve into members of the audience for the arts. It might also be beneficial for cognitive or emotional development to be engaged with the arts. In an even more instrumental way, arts education may be initiated with the goal of creating external effects, such as getting higher grades in maths or creating a more caring school climate. This course will look at the different ways in which the arts have been taught inside and outside of schools, what the aims have been, and to what extent claims regarding the impact of engagement with the arts can be substantiated. For that purpose, different approaches to arts education will be addressed, ranging from approaches that focus mainly on teaching art history to approaches that prefer to stimluate spontaneous expression through the arts. Students will evaluate their own experiences with arts education and develop a plan for an arts course based on the literature and examples discussed in class</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will familiarize students with a number of central concepts and insights with regard to arts education as it takes place both within shools and in cultural institutions. We will discuss the goals that arts education sets for itself, the methods by which the arts are taught, and the potential impact of arts education on people’s cognition and well-being

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course offers an overview of state-of-the-art approaches to understanding media and how its intertwined with arts and culture. To consider how arts, culture and media feature in various process together we review their relationship via several crucial elements. First, we focus on the media industry (strategies, conventions, but also business models). Second, we address media consumers and users (from artists circulating content to fans consuming it). Furthermore, we consider different technologies (platforms, increasing digitization of the industry) and media content (via questions of representation and diversity).

We focus on these different areas in and through which we can understand the relationship between arts, culture, and media, via a variety of case studies. The course aims to emphasize and include current developments in the media industry, in a global perspective to provide context and comparison. We will the course’s main concepts and cases via in-depth discussions of the course work and student assignments, in-class assignments, and presentations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Key theories and approaches to the study of media and its role in society, particularly its relation to arts and culture;
• Key concepts like the media industry, media and its consumers, media technologies and media content;
• The social, political, cultural and economic impacts of media, and how this relates the fields of arts and culture.
• Apply and reflect on relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings discussing arts, culture and media;
• Formulate their own viewpoints on arts, culture and media;
• Analyse and communicate their knowledge in written and oral form.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114663,2023,Assessing the impact of Culture and Creativity in Society,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EMMP Loots'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What is the impact of a cultural organisation? Does it create societal impact? If so, how much? What would have occurred if the organisation would not have existed, and what would occur if the organisation would cease to exist? Those questions can be addressed by impact assessment, which is useful not only because it provides insight in the scope and size of an organisation’s impact, but also because it offers the opportunity to learn and to navigate the organisation. All organisations have an impact on society. This impact can include both intended and unintended effects, which in turn can be either positive or negative. Organisations are increasingly being held responsible for these effects.

The present course entails a scientifically-grounded approach to impact assessment, with a focus on arts, culture, and creativity. In line with the new Strategy 2024 of the Erasmus University (‘Creating Positive Societal Impact’), the course provides students with the knowledge, skills, tools and experience for conducting a social impact assessment in the cultural sector, in close collaboration with cultural organisations and with the involvement of experts.

The course is developed by means of a collaboration between the Erasmus School for History, Culture and Communication (https://www.eur.nl/en/eshcc/), and the Impact Centre Erasmus (https://www.eur.nl/ice/).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The course prepares students for the cultural labour market by giving them a deep understanding of the roles that organisations can play in society and equip them with the tools to effectively assess these roles, in a close dialogue with people working in the field. It teaches students how to conduct a social impact study: Students learn how to develop and validate a theory of change for a cultural organisation and how to develop a measurement plan; they will collect and analyse the data needed for the impact assessment of a cultural organisation; they will present and report their results.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, theoretical perspectives on assessment and its impact on learning will be discussed. In the first part of the course, the concept of “testing as a tool for learning” will be presented in relation to how this can facilitate student/employee learning. Assessment can be a powerful device in aiding learners in their learning process and facilitating learning outcomes. Concepts such as self-regulated learning and formative assessment will be specifically discussed. Additionally, data-driven teaching and adaptive training will be explored in order to present teachers/trainers with evidence-based tools for curriculum development.

In the high-stakes testing culture, which is characterized by large incentives for good performance and negative consequences for poor performance, people often experience anxiety and perform more poorly on exams than expected given their skill level. The second project of this course is about strategies to optimize test performance. These strategies will focus on characteristics of the learner/testee, the teacher, the learning/test task, and the test environment.

Assessment in education and training needs to be accurate to make valid instruments that can be used for future learning and development of students or employees. However, assessments are prone to preconceived or unreasoned opinions or feelings, also called biases. Bias in self-assessments, peer assessments, teacher or trainer assessments, or in testing in general, endanger the accuracy of assessment. In the third part of the course you will learn about different types of bias in assessment and testing, and what can be done to reduce or prevent them.

Peer assessment can be an important educational tool for both teachers and students. Teachers can use peer assessment to reduce their workload and students can use it to enhance their learning. In the fourth project of this course, you will learn about peer-assessment, identifying effective forms of peer assessment, the underlying cognitive mechanisms, necessary conditions, and characteristics of effective peer feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students will be able to identify the role testing/assessment has in the regulation of the learning process and apply the concept of testing as a tool for learning in order to facilitate student/employee learning.

• Students will be able to apply knowledge about methods to improve learning outcomes (test performance) by managing characteristics of the learner/testee, the teacher, the learning/test task, and the test environment.

• Students will be able to identify biases in self-assessment, peer assessment, teacher/trainer assessments and testing in general as well as critique tests and testing practices in order to reduce or prevent biases.

• Students will be able to apply knowledge about effective forms of peer assessment, its underlying mechanisms, necessary conditions for peer assessment, and characteristics of effective peer feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to provide a profound and state-of-the-art insight into asset pricing, both from a theoretical and empirical perspective. The field of asset pricing aims to explain the prices of financial assets such as stocks, fixed income instruments and derivative securities. The field is highly relevant for financial management, because asset pricing models form the basis for many practical management applications such as capital budgeting, risk management, portfolio selection and performance evaluation. During this course, you will be introduced to the key insights from 50 years of theoretical, empirical and methodological research. The course consists of two parts. One part focuses on the theory of asset pricing in the unifying framework of stochastic discount factors. The other part concentrates on testing asset pricing models and covers both empirical and methodological issues.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You learn what factor models are and the role they play in asset pricing.
• You learn about the derivation, implications and testing of the CAPM.
• You learn how to test factor models.
• You learn about firm and asset characteristics, cross-sectional anomalies, and how they are related to asset pricing models.
• You learn about the utility-based approach to asset pricing.
• You learn about the market-based approach to asset pricing.
• You learn about machine learning techniques in asset pricing.
• You learn how to design research in asset pricing.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. R.J.A. Laeven (UvA), Prof. Dr. ir. M.H. Vellekoop (UvA)

This course provides an introductory yet comprehensive and rigorous treatment of modern asset pricing theory. Asset pricing is concerned with determining the value of an uncertain future payoff. Equivalently, it is concerned with explaining (variation in) expected returns on risky assets. It covers the following topics:
1. Expected utility, risk aversion and single period portfolio choice;
4. Stochastic discount factors and the Fundamental Theorem of Asset Pricing;
5. Dynamic programming and pricing in incomplete markets;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Financial statements are an important source of information for stakeholders like shareholders, creditors, employees, and the general public, to value their prospective claims. Over time, accounting scandals, like Enron, Worldcom, AIG, Lehman Brothers, and most recently Wirecard, have indicated that managers have incentives to use their discretion to affect financial reporting in order to serve their own benefits. Thus, to reassure stakeholders and restore and strengthen their confidence in financial statements, regulators require firms to have their financial statements assured by third parties, namely auditors or certified public accountants (CPAs). CPAs are the equivalent to Dutch registered accountants. This course addresses the function and relevance of auditors in more detail and considers the decisions and dilemmas that auditors are faced with as part of their job.
Attendance of lectures and workshops is voluntary, but highly recommended.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain the demand for audit and other assurance services, the organization of the CPA profession and the types of services they provide
• Evaluate the audit responsibilities and objectives, the ethical and independence responsibilities, and legal liability of CPAs
• Assess audit risk and a company’s internal controls
• Perform tests of controls, substantive tests of transactions, substantive analytical procedures, and tests of details of balances
• Describe the completion phase of the audit
• Formulate an audit opinion for a given audit situation
• Understand the effects of technological advancements on auditing
• Develop in teams multiple viewpoints on specific auditing cases and scientific articles
• Conduct a presentation of a scientific article

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het Atelier bestaat uit een drietal sporen:

column2: • Design Atelier: Studenten gaan aan de slag met een ontwerpopdracht van een externe praktijkopdrachtgever. Onder begeleiding van een docent managen de studenten de samenwerking met de opdrachtgever en andere betrokkenen, van het eerste overleg over de vraag van de opdrachtgever tot het opleveren van het advies en zorgen dat dit wordt ingebed in de beleidspraktijk. De opdrachtgevende organisatie speelt een belangrijke rol in de aansturing en de beoordeling van de ontwerpopdracht. Studenten nemen kennis van het ontwerpgericht denken en leren de verschillende stappen en activiteiten die in een bestuurskundig ontwerpproces toegepast kunnen worden. Aan de hand van een concrete casus die door een praktijkorganisatie is ingebracht, passen ze deze ontwerpbenadering toe en werken ze toe naar een praktisch bruikbaar ontwerp (voor bijvoorbeeld een proces, een beleidsinstrument of een sturingsaanpak) dat past bij de vraag van de opdrachtgever.

• Workshops met professionals: We organiseren, gedurende het jaar, workshops met professionals uit de praktijk die in hun werk met complexe bestuurlijke vraagstukken te maken krijgen. Met hen wordt stilgestaan bij de professionele vaardigheden die de bestuurskundige professional moet hebben, met name als het aankomt op het opereren in complexe maatschappelijke en politiek-bestuurlijke contexten. De exacte opzet kan per workshop verschillen, maar het uitgangspunt is dat de studenten na een interactieve presentatie van de gastspreker aan de slag gaan met een opdracht (tijdens de workshop) waarvan ze het eindresultaat aan de gastspreker zullen presenteren.
• Methodenseminars: Gedurende het stage- en scriptietraject worden er, als onderdeel van het Atelier, ook methodenseminars aangeboden ter ondersteuning van het uitvoeren van het scriptieonderzoek.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na afloop van de module kan de student:

column2: • Relevante ontwerpmethoden en -technieken identificeren en selecteren om deze in een concrete casus toe te passen.
• Middels deze ontwerpbenadering een gefundeerd en bruikbaar ontwerp ontwikkelen.
• Op professionele wijze werken in opdracht van een opdrachtgever.
• Bewust op eigen rol, positie, assumpties en inbreng in het ontwerpproces reflecteren.
• Constructieve feedback geven aan anderen ten behoeve van het ontwerpproces.
• Theoretische inzichten uit de literatuur over complexiteit gebruiken om ideeën voor oplossingen aan te dragen voor problemen in de bestuurskundige praktijk.
• Reflecteren op de meerwaarde van de eigen opgedane kennis en competenties voor het toekomstige werkveld.

column1: In het atelier introductie bestuurskunde wordt de student vertrouwd gemaakt met de beoefening van de bestuurswetenschappen. In werkgroepverband komen diverse onderwerpen aan de orde, waarop in het latere verloop van de opleiding verdere verdieping plaatsvindt. Door het kleinschalige karakter en de op samenwerking gerichte werkwijze wordt gestimuleerd dat de studenten zich snel thuis voelen aan de universiteit. Tevens krijgen zij een beeld voorgeschoteld van de analytische houding die in een academische omgeving van hen verwacht wordt. De werkvormen bestaan voornamelijk uit discussies en schrijfopdrachten. Inhoudelijk wordt aangesloten bij de vakken Inleiding Beleid en Inleiding Management (van de minor Beleid en Management in de Publieke Sector). Onderwerpen uit deze vakken worden toegepast op de praktijk, waarbij zoveel mogelijk aansluiting met de actualiteit wordt gezocht.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De student is na het volgen van dit vak in staat tot het:
-              Analyseren van basisbegrippen in wetenschappelijke teksten,
-              Zelfstandig en in groepen werkzaamheden op academisch niveau uitvoeren,
-              Op academisch niveau argumenteren, presenteren en refereren.</body>
